title: 110_s2950
content:
The Act titled "Helping HANDS for Autism Act of 2008" establishes the Autism Navigator Program under the Public Health Service Act. The "Helping HANDS for Autism Act of 2008" establishes a grant program for eligible entities to develop autism navigator programs, improving coordination of health, housing, education, and social services for individuals with autism spectrum disorder. Eligible entities must have at least 2 years of experience in serving the autism community. The "Helping HANDS for Autism Act of 2008" requires eligible entities to have staff with expertise in applied behavioral analysis, autism spectrum disorders, and rehabilitation for individuals with autism spectrum disorder. The "Helping HANDS for Autism Act of 2008" mandates that eligible entities must have staff trained in autism spectrum disorders. The Secretary has the authority to determine eligible entities. To apply for a grant, an eligible entity must submit an application with specified information and assurances to the Secretary. The application must also include a commitment to provide ongoing outreach services. The Secretary will determine the functions of autism navigators under the grant, which may include coordinating and scheduling for individuals with autism spectrum disorders and their families. The functions of autism navigators may include coordinating appointments, referrals, community outreach, transportation assistance, housing arrangements, education assistance, insurance help, case management, psychosocial assessment, care coordination of health services, and referral to other community services. The autism navigators provide referrals, financial support, service coordination, health insurance coverage assistance, and partnerships within the healthcare and advocacy community. The autism navigators work with the healthcare and advocacy community to assist the underserved autism community by notifying individuals about clinical trials, helping them overcome barriers in accessing services, and coordinating with State departments for various services. The autism navigators provide caregiver supports, mentoring, and resources for individuals with autism spectrum disorder and their families. They also offer culturally sensitive support and serve as expert resources for accessing early intervention services. The eligible entity receiving a grant will develop an autism navigator program to recruit, train, and supervise autism navigators. Grants will support access to early intervention services, health insurance, housing programs, financial security programs, Medicare, and Medicaid services. The autism navigator program developed under the grant shall be for a maximum of 5 years, subject to annual approval by the Secretary and availability of appropriations. There is no limit on the number of grants that can be awarded to eligible entities. The program will reach out to doctor's offices and treatment centers to encourage referrals for individuals with autism spectrum disorder. The autism navigator program developed under the grant aims to train navigators with direct knowledge of communities, health insurance systems, and evidence-based practices for individuals with autism spectrum disorder. The autism navigator program assigns navigators to manage care and assist individuals with autism spectrum disorder in navigating services. It provides centralized access to Federal and State programs related to autism spectrum disorders. The autism navigator program is carried out by various agencies including the Administration for Children and Families, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and others. The autism navigator program, implemented by different agencies, requires grant recipients to collect specific data on services provided and ensure confidentiality of participant information. The grant recipients of the autism navigator program must collect and protect participant information, including aggregate data that is not individually identifiable. Recipients are required to submit an annual report to the Secretary summarizing collected data and identifying needs for navigation services. The Secretary will conduct evaluations to assess the impact of autism navigator services and coordinate the program with other relevant programs. The section clarifies that payment is not required for navigation services or other services provided free of charge under the Autism Navigator Program. SEC. 201. TRAINING OF FIRST RESPONDERS IN THE RECOGNITION OF AUTISM. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, along with other federal agencies, will develop a standard curriculum for training first responders to assist individuals with autism and other cognitive disabilities during emergencies. Grants will be awarded to States and local governments for training first responders in providing assistance to individuals with autism. Training under this section will educate first responders on the risks of autism and cognitive disabilities, as well as teach appropriate recognition and response techniques. TITLE III--HOME OF THEIR OWN

SEC. 301. HOME OF THEIR OWN.

(a) Task Force.--Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will convene a task force with national and State autism advocacy groups, housing recipients, and community organizations serving adults with autism spectrum disorder.
(b) Grant Program.--The task force will establish a housing grant program for adults with autism spectrum disorder to provide individualized housing and services.
